body: Is it possible to move JIRA and close this pull request?
Sounds good @takezoe, though I am still unclear what this issue really is.

I also agree with takezoe!

@mars `BatchPredict` seems to make multiple SparkContexts. The `WorkflowContext.apply` method creates a new instance of the SparkContext class.
https://github.com/apache/incubator-predictionio/blob/v0.12.0-incubating/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/predictionio/workflow/BatchPredict.scala#L160
https://github.com/apache/incubator-predictionio/blob/v0.12.0-incubating/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/predictionio/workflow/BatchPredict.scala#L183
Is this supposed to be this way?

@shimamoto yes, it requires two SparkContexts because PredictionIO implicitly stops the first one after preparing deploy, so it cannot be reused for the second instance to run queries.

I don‚Äôt understand what causes this error here, as the two SparkContexts normally work correctly.

> yes, it requires two SparkContexts because PredictionIO implicitly stops the first one after preparing deploy, so it cannot be reused for the second instance to run queries.

@mars Oh, I see. But when using a persisted model, PredictionIO don't stop the first SparkContext.
https://github.com/apache/incubator-predictionio/blob/v0.12.0-incubating/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/predictionio/controller/Engine.scala#L241-L250

I guess this causes, for example, if we use the Recommendation Engine Template, which supports loading a persisted model ([see](https://github.com/apache/incubator-predictionio-template-recommender/blob/develop/src/main/scala/ALSModel.scala)).

@shimamoto  Ah, this makes so much sense now üò≤ Not sure of a solution, yet. I created a JIRA for this issue: [PIO-138 Batch predict fails when using a PersistentModel](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PIO-138). Let's continue discussion for a fix there.
Is there a way to close this issue other than commit message?
I'm currently testing this change with various engines and large batches.

Tested this new `pio batchpredict` with all three model types:

* ‚úÖ custom PersistentModel (ALS Recommendation)
* ‚úÖ built-in, default model serialization (Classification)
* ‚úÖ null model (Universal Recommender)

This PR is ready to go!
BTW, I found performance for a large, 250K query batch running on a single multi-core machine is equivalent to the previous Spark RDD-based performance.

This PR stalled due to @dszeto's concerns about removing the distributed processing capability from `pio batchpredict`. I agree that distributed batch processing is optimal, but do not have a solution for the nested RDDs problem encountered for RDD-based persistent models.
LGTM. Thanks!
@takezoe Unfortunately we can only close PRs with a commit message at this point. Gitbox may help but it has not been working for me.

@voran Thank you for your contribution! Would you please fix the license check test, file a ticket under Apache JIRA (https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/PIO/issues) and change the subject of this PR to have the ticket number please?

@dszeto I see. I found an empty commit to close PRs: https://github.com/apache/spark/commit/f217d7d9b22c4b9c947fc5467379af17f036ee61
They are making such commits periodically. So I'll close this PR by a same way later.
LGTM. Thanks @ramands ! Can you change the base branch to `livedoc` so that it updates the live web site immediately, please?
@dszeto Done! üëç
@dszeto Did I miss out on anything?

Can you resolve the conflict?
The `README.md` file is quite outdated.
@ramands Nope. Sorry I dropped the ball. I will merge this now. Thanks!

@tom-chan I think @DanVisan is referring to https://github.com/apache/predictionio-template-attribute-based-classifier/blob/develop/src/main/scala/Evaluation.scala. That is what is being linked from this file right now.

Got it. In that case do you mind updating other instances of `org.template.classification.` to `org.example.classification.` on this page, as well as docs/manual/source/evaluation/metricbuild.html.md? Thanks.

@dszeto is right. What i meant to say is that the package names in this tutorial should be renamed from `org.template.classification` to `org.example.classification` because this tutorial links to https://github.com/apache/predictionio-template-attribute-based-classifier/blob/develop/src/main/scala/Evaluation.scala which probably was updated so the tutorial is now obsolete.
Would be great if you also update `docs/manual/source/evaluation/metricbuild.html.md` in the same tutorial series. Thanks!
@tom-chan i updated `docs/manual/source/evaluation/metricbuild.html.md`. Thanks for noticing!
LGTM
Fixes for sources and docs should be separated pull requests. Pull request sources to `develop` branch is OK, but docs should be targetted `livedoc` branch.
@takezoe Thank you for your response. I've pushed with only source code changes. I will make another pull request for docs.
@seratch Great. Thanks for your contribution!
LGTM!
Some test patterns have failed on Travis, but they seem to be not related to this pull request. So I'm going to merge.

@jirotubuyaki Thank you for adding a new template.
I would like to update PIO documentation after this PR be merged.
For that, could you change a target branch from `develop` to `livedoc`.

Guidelines are here: http://predictionio.incubator.apache.org/community/contribute-documentation/

In short;
* Use the livedoc branch if you want to update the current documentation.
* Use the develop branch if you want to write documentation for the next release.
@dszeto Could you take a look?

Looks like 2 major potentially breaking changes are in as well:

* Dropping Java 7 support
* Dropping Spark 1.3 to 1.5 support

Should we instead put out a deprecation notice for those as well before dropping?

Well...I don't think we need to put out a deprecation notice because these versions no longer meet prerequisites we expose.
https://github.com/apache/predictionio/blob/livedoc/docs/manual/source/install/index.html.md.erb#L22

or rather, it's a bug and should be fixed. Would you like me to separate it from this PR?
@shimamoto Good call. Those have been updated for a year already.
Thank you! Merged. Web site should be updated momentarily.
I am merging this.
May one of PMCs please take a look?
Let us look at the result of Travis build first. :-)

Travis has all passed and I checked following things:

- `make-distribution.sh -Dspark.version=2.3.1` on my local PC
- build, train and deploy [text recommendation template](https://predictionio.apache.org/templates/recommendation/quickstart/) with it and MLLib 2.3.1

There wasn't any problem. We can add Spark 2.3 support. üëç
Thank you @takezoe! Will merge soon.
Thanks @JulienGremillot !
@shimamoto Can we include this fix in the forthcoming 0.13.0 release?
@takezoe Sure thing!

The official docker support is nice! and I was impressed your idea which composite PredictionIO's configuration by compositing docker-compose.yml by `-f` option!

However I think docker-compose is just for quick start for users, not for production use because we would need to create our own Spark cluster or Elasticsearch cluster if we need them outside of a PredictionIO instance. For this purpose, I think a fixed minimal structure of docker-compose.yml (e.g. PIO + PostgreSQL + Spark) is sufficient.

Further, if we will offer the docker support officially, it would be nice if we can put a docker image to Apache registry (but I don't know how can we do it!):
https://hub.docker.com/r/apache/

Thank you for your feedback.

> However I think docker-compose is just for quick start for users

I have a plan to support Kubernetes after this PR.
To do that, I consider that Kompose generates K8s' yml files for production use.
So, I think that this multiple docker compose files are for production.

Ah, your plan is that creating whole PredictionIO enviornment indcluding Spark cluster and storage cluster on the Kubernetes cluster, right? That was beyond my imagination, really exciting! If so, it would be nice if we can support HDFS, HBase and various managed services on the cloud as well.

I have some questions about Dockerfile, so I will make comments later. But basically agree with your Kubernetes support plan.
One way we can proceed is to mark the `Dockerfile` and the image it generates as official. Helper scripts and compose files can be marked as official reference. Good work @marevol !

> your plan is that creating whole PredictionIO enviornment indcluding Spark cluster and storage cluster on the Kubernetes cluster

Yes, and also you can use external clusters to specify it in docker-compose.[meta|event].yml.
Test failed in some patterns, but we can ignore test results because all modifications in this pull request are for the documentation.

Wow. Thank you @takezoe !

I took a look at the increased number of build failures. I am going to put in a potential fix once my fork passed building.
Thank you @takezoe !
LGTM. Regarding automation, I think we can create scripts for some steps inside the doc.
Thanks @EmergentOrder ! Do you also have a migration tool for this change? It would be nice if existing users have a way to upgrade.
Please tag this PR with [PIO-168](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PIO-168).

@shimamoto If you don't mind, please add the missing step that makes a release on JIRA (https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/PIO?selectedItem=com.atlassian.jira.jira-projects-plugin%3Arelease-page&status=no-filter).

Actually, according to the docs, existing indices, and so apps, should continue to work in 6.X (but will be disallowed in 7.X). I assume there is a documented ES migration process. There may be exceptions in template code, such as in the UR where the urindex is hot-swapped. I haven't tested this, but I will. 

Assuming that existing apps keep working, and on (re)creation they work, from the user's perspective I don't see a disruption / need for a PIO migration tool. This obviously doesn't hold for when we get to ES 7 though.

Scratch that, apps won't continue to work, although the indices will. We could add a fallback to the old indices in the code, but I think we should prefer to advise users to recreate and retrain their app when they upgrade.
If users want to update to 6.X without the possibility to create new apps, but with existing apps preserved, they can use ES migration and PIO 0.13.0.
I think we should provide a migration tool if possible. I will file another ticket for that.
We should also update `bin/pio-class` to require Spark 2.0.0+. It is currently set to 1.6.3.
I added Spark 2.0.2 / Hadoop 2.6.5 test patterns and updated Spark version in `bin/pio-class.sh` and `tools/src/main/scala/org/apache/predictionio/tools/commands/Management.scala`.
@dszeto Sure! You mean you want me to add the step that creates a next version after a release?
@takezoe Looks great. I have no further comments. Thank you!
That would be great too. What I meant was we need to mark the version as released on JIRA. If you don‚Äôt see the option in JIRA please let me know.
Just stumbled upon https://github.com/apache/predictionio/blob/develop/data/src/main/spark-1/org/apache/predictionio/data/SparkVersionDependent.scala. We probably should clean this up as well.
@dszeto Nice catch! I removed the file.
I fixed it!
LGTM. Merging. Thank you!
@marevol Is there further updates to this PR? Is this ready for merging?
Merging. Thank you!

It's okay to merge this PR.
For a release procedure, I'll file a new issue on JIRA and update PMC.md.
LGTM!
Thanks @shimamoto !
@shimamoto Can you take a look?
@EmergentOrder is this ready to merge? I was waiting for build to pass but it looks like a transient error to me. Do you mind resolving the conflicts? It should trigger a new build.
+1 from me
LGTM. Merging. Thanks!

Fixed the conflicts. I agree, looked like a transient error.
Ready to merge, pending the next build.
@dszeto Thanks!
LGTM!
CC: @dszeto @shimamoto
Thanks! Merging.
@dszeto Thanks!

Updated:
- Set v0.13.0 as a default build tag
- Use --build-arg option to change a tag/branch

I'll merge this PR if there are no other concerns.

Please review and let me know if I missed anything.
Thanks a lot for your support guys.
PPythonEventStore is used in python/pypio.

What is your opinion about this comment?
https://github.com/apache/predictionio/pull/462#discussion_r218608459

My another concern license of MySQL driver which is discussed for the binary distribution in the dev list recently.

Is it ok to include MySQL driver in the official docker image? I guess it's ok because this Dockerfile is in the official repository but docker image is delivered from DockerHub. So we can say: "It's not a distribution managed under ASF." But I'm not sure this logic is valid.
LGTM!
Yeah, it's necessary for python/pypio for now. We can probably remove it after supporting Spark ML natively.

IntelliJ was unable to figure out the usage of PPythonEventOperator in python module.
How do you guys check this? (or do i need to find the word usage through whole project)

> What is your opinion about this comment?

Does --build-arg option solve it?
You can change a branch or tag when building a docker image.

Just in case, I moved MySQL download process into pio_run.

> Does --build-arg option solve it?

Using `--build-arg` is nice! But I mean it would be nice if we can create a docker image on my working copy before commit and push something. But this is my opinion. Don't mind if you don't need it.

> Just in case, I moved MySQL download process into pio_run.

Good idea. This solution can be applied to setup of native distributions.
@shimamoto Thanks!!
LGTM. Thank you!
LGTM. Merging. Thanks @saurabh3091 !
@shimamoto All tests passed. Could you take a look?
Not sure if that last failure was transient or what, but it looks like there are source dependencies on commons-lang3, so I added it to common/build.sbt.
